thread.title: Even idle, the Patriots still prove to be better than the rest of the NFL - Patriots
thread.title_full: Even idle, the Patriots still prove to be better than the rest of the NFL - Patriots

author: Eric Wilbur
title: Even idle, the Patriots still prove to be better than the rest of the NFL - Patriots
text:
COMMENTARY
Even idle, we still learned a little more about the New England Patriots on Sunday.
Actually, maybe it was more reaffirmation of what most of us already know.
 The Patriots are still better than most everybody else.
Give them Jacksonville. Give them Pittsburgh. Give them the Green Bay Packers, the Cincinnati Bengals, or another run at the Seattle Seahawks.
It doesn’t really seem like much should slow the Patriots down on the road to the Super Bowl.
They’ve all but won the AFC East already, particularly considering the coaching prowesses of Rex Ryan and Joe Philbin— whom the Miami Dolphins fired on Monday —on Sunday, each of whom performed his job with the strategic thinking of an empty soda can while Patriots coach Bill Belichick was enjoying his bye week. That’s not to sleep on the 3-1 New York Jets by any stretch, but let’s see what Todd Bowles’ team can do in Foxborough in a few weeks before anyone considers them a viable threat in the division.
As for the rest of the AFC, the Cincinnati Bengals remained undefeated with an impressive win over the Kansas City Chiefs, but we’re finding out more and more on a weekly basis now that the Chiefs kinda suck.
Denver? Peyton Manning looked like he was facing a Belichick defensive scheme as the Minnesota Vikings, who picked the Denver Broncos’ quarterback off twice, nearly left Mile High with an upset victory.
The San Diego Chargers snuck past the lowly Cleveland Browns. The Baltimore Ravens won in desperation against the Pittsburgh Steelers Thursday night for their first win of the season. The 2-2 Oakland Raiders are sort of a cute, early-season storyline to take note of before they inevitably fade away.
Then there are the Indianapolis Colts. Insert your own punch line.
The Colts got their second win of the season Sunday, but it was without starting quarterback Andrew Luck, who missed the game with an injured shoulder, and it was by the slightest of margins, 16-13, over the same hapless Jacksonville Jaguars who the Patriots trounced to the tune of 51-17 last weekend. Style points aside, the Colts have only scored 72 points so far this season through four games, placing Indy’s offense in the lower rungs of the NFL.
No matter how you want to dress up the Colts’ win over Jacksonville (will they be raising a banner commemorating the victory later this week?), led by 40-year-old backup Matt Hasselbeck, this season was already beginning to look ugly before Luck went down.
So it’s somewhat disappointing that here we sit, only 13 days from the Sunday night showdown at Lucas Oil Stadium between the Patriots and Colts, with coach Chuck Pagano’s (who is morphing into Pete Carroll, circa 1997, with every rah-rah speech after each unimpressive victory) team in shambles. The Colts, of course, were the preseason darlings of a number of prognosticators (many with a Bristol, Conn. address), only to start somewhat flat. After an offseason of Colts media and fans pea-cocking for their roles in Deflategate, that mid-October showdown was supposed to be pigskin Armageddon, a battle between the two AFC favorites vying for the conference crown.
Instead, it’s shaping up to be just be another rout by New England. Who’s going to pound 200 rushing yards against the Colts this time around? Does it matter?
The Patriots have 13 games remaining on their 2015 schedule, and the remaining opponents are a combined 21-22. While I’m not subscribing to the notion that Patriots are going 19-0, believing instead that the team will trip up somewhere along the way, the evidence is starting to suggest I may be an idiot.
As it stands now, the Broncos and the Jets are the only teams on the schedule, as currently constituted, with winning records. The decimated Dallas Cowboys are up next at 2-2.
“They’re a good football team,” Belichick said of the Cowboys during a conference call on Sunday. “I know they’ve lost a couple key players, but they’ll be getting some more guys back next week, and they’ve got a lot of players to work with. It’s going to be a big challenge for us.”
Translation: “Next.”
The Colts travel to Houston Thursday night to try to amass three wins heading into their game with New England, a rematch of last January’s AFC title game.
The AFC South (five wins among four teams in the entire division) is terrible, so the Colts won’t be going away entirely. With the Tennessee Titans, Texans, and Jaguars sitting behind doors No. 2-4, it would take an even bigger collapse for Indianapolis to not sit atop the division once the regular season ends.
But they proved yet again on Sunday that they’re nowhere near ready to take on the New England Patriots in less than two weeks.
Let’s face it though. Nobody is.
Where the Patriots called home before Gillette
Previous -- of -- Next The Foxborough Bay State Raceway was the proposed site of a new Patriots stadium in 1970. The Boston Patriots had played in various venues in the city for their first 11 seasons, including Fenway Park from 1963 to 1968. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Phil Fine (left) and Dan Marr examined a model of the new stadium prior to its construction in 1971. The stadium would become the first home of the New England Patriots. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The exterior of the Patriots' new stadium, Schaefer Stadium, in 1971. The stadium was built in just 327 days at a cost of $7.1 million. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Work was finished on the stadium's bleachers before the first game. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next August 15, 1971: Opening night at Schaefer Stadium. Gino Cappelletti booted a 36-yard field goal for the first points scored in the stadium. Opening night included a massive traffic jam getting out of the stadium. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The team entered the field for the first-ever game in the their new home at Schaefer Stadium in Foxborough. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The opening night crowd of 60,423 was the largest ever at a Massachusetts sporting event. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots beat the New York Giants 20-14 in their first game in the new stadium. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next An aerial view of the stadium's parking lot at game time during the team's first season. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Another view from the sky during the first season of Schaefer Stadium. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Schaefer Stadium also served as a venue for concerts. This is a shot of the venue from 1975. Groups such as the Allman Brothers Band, Chicaco, J. Geils Band, and the Beach Boys played the stadium that year. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next New luxury boxes were added to the stadium in 1982. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The stadium was renamed Sullivan Stadium in 1983 in honor of the Sullivan family, majority owners of the Patriots. This is an empty concourse inside the stadium in 1982. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The stadium also housed events ike motocross racing. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next In 1983, fans huddle under blankets against the December snow in a game against the New Orleans Saints. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Fans attempted to beat the heat on a hot day at Sullivan Stadium in 1985. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Patriot fans gave their team a spirited sendoff after a 34-23 win over the Cincinnati Bengals during the 1985 season that put the Patriots into the playoffs as a wild card team. New England would earn their first Super Bowl berth during the 1985-86 season. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Empty stands at Sullivan Stadium during the players' strike of 1987. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Fans sat on top of port-a-potties to get a view over the crowds at a Grateful Dead concert in 1987. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The exterior of Sullivan Stadium in 1987. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Patriots ownership changed hands from the Sullivans to Victor Kiam in 1987 and the venue became Foxboro Stadium. Here the sign is lowered from the front of the stadium. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Foxboro Stadium received a natural turf makeover before the 1991 season. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The edges of the field were expanded to accomodate the 1994 Soccer World Cup. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Fans lined up for season tickets at the beginning of the 1994 season. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The lights turned on for a night game at Foxboro Stadium during the 1994 season. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Quarterback Drew Bledsoe and head coach Bill Parcells are pictured during the 1994 season at Foxboro Stadium. The pair, with help from new ownership in Robert Kraft, helped lay the Patriots winning foundation. Foxboro Stadium provided many great moments in the mid-90s, including a Super Bowl run in 1995-96. Jim Davis / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Adam Vinitieri was hoisted up by his fellow Patriots in the legendary final game at Foxboro Stadium. Vinatieri kicked the game-winning field goal against the Raiders in the famous Snow Bowl of the 2001 season, advancing the Patriots to the AFC Championship game. C.J. Gunther / Reuters
